executive_summary: Entertainment insurers can provide industry services to companies and individuals involved in entertainment production such as film, television and live performances. Industry operators provide insurance policies to protect staff, equipment and rentals from injury, damage or loss. The industry is an indispensable part of risk management in the entertainment industry. Many entertainment companies view policies as inelastic, although some may choose to decrease consumption of insurance policies should premium prices increase too much. Similar to other insurance industries, policy pricing fluctuates between cycles of price-cutting (softening) and price-raising (hardening). Over the past five years, revenue has grown at a CAGR of 2.7% to $27.5 billion, including an expected 1.6% increase in 2024. Profit is expected to lag to 10.5% of revenue in 2024 from 13.3% in 2019.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Consumer Spending on Entertainment Due to Rising Disposable Income Supports Revenue Growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The Entertainment Insurance industry provides property, casualty, liability and other insurance for film and TV production, concerts, festivals, theatres and other entertainment providers. While there are other factors that determine industry premium values, demand for industry services is closely linked to the financial performance of entertainment industries. In the latter part of the current period, consumer spending on entertainment has increased as disposable income levels have grown, resulting in positive growth for the industry.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: THE INDUSTRY EXPANDS AMID THE PANDEMIC
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Industry revenue experienced limited growth in 2020 amid the pandemic, despite significant drops in demand from concert and event promotion and in domestic trips by US residents. Due to shutdowns brought on by the pandemic, concerts, performances and festivals were temporarily prohibited in most parts of the United States. As film and TV sets have reopened following the pandemic, entertainment insurance has been in high demand, since operating these productions while the virus still present carries a high degree of risk.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: INDUSTRY PROFIT SHRINKS AMID THE PANDEMIC AND DUE TO CLIMBING WAGE EXPENSES
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: As the virus began to spread in the United States in early 2020, performances and concerts were forced to either postpone or cancel, while film and TV sets were forced to shut down production. Due to these cancelations, industry companies were required to pay out on cancelation policies, which ensured that production companies did not experience massive debts if they were unable to put on events. As a result of these higher expenses amid the pandemic, industry companies generated less profit in 2020. As lockdown measures were lifted the industry was able to grow industry profit from pandemic-lows, however, industry profit has not grown to pre-pandemic levels. Wage growth has outpaced revenue growth over the past five years, putting downward pressure on industry profit.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: POSITIVE ECONOMIC TRENDS WILL SUPPORT INDUSTRY DEMAND
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The Entertainment Insurance industry is expected to benefit from robust growth over the next five years. As demand from concert and event promotion is expected to climb, this will support the growth in demand for entertainment insurance. Over the next five years, domestic trips by US residents are expected to rebound and will support the growing demand for entertainment insurance. Consumers often take domestic flights to attend performances in other parts of the United States.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: THE INDUSTRY IS EXPECTED TO EXPERIENCE PROFIT GROWTH
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The industry is expected to encounter strong demand and revenue growth over the next five years. In addition, industry profit, measured as earnings before interest and taxes, is expected to climb as per capita disposable income rises. While revenue is expected to surge, operating costs will also likely climb as additional employees are expected to be needed to keep up with higher demand. As a result, industry profit growth will be limited over the next five years.

industry_definition: This industry provides insurance coverage to companies and people involved in producing a film, television show or live performance. Typical insurance policies are designed to protect staff, equipment, rentals and locations from loss, injury or damage.

opportunities: High Performance Drivers: Per capita disposable income

key_trends: Rising disposable income has supported industry revenue growth. In the latter part of the current period, consumer spending on entertainment climbed due to high levels of disposable income, which supported the industry.

The industry will benefit from positive economic trends over the next five years. The demand from concert and event promotion and domestic trips by US residents is expected to jump, which will boost industry demand.

Statutory Accounting Principles: Insurers must use a unique accounting system when filing annual financial reports with state regulators and the Internal Revenue Service. This system is known as statutory accounting principles (SAP).

Industry Segments: Property and casualty insurance comprises the largest segment for operators. Property and casualty insurance protects filming equipment and film sets from damages and losses, which can be expensive. Theatrical productions require industry services to be protected against possible disruptions. Theatrical productions protect against damages during live performances and rehearsals.

Competition: Price is the primary form of competition. Insurers deliver added value by providing products that meet individual risk needs and circumstances for consumers. Operators must be able to assess risk efficiently. Data analytics help operators better assess risk. Operators compete based on the quality of employees. Underwriting processes emphasize high-quality risks and are critical due to the limited number of individuals with these skill sets. Operators seek to develop cost-effective distribution systems. Low-cost product distribution channels typically include the use of agents and underwriters.

Industry profit has declined over the past five years due to climbing wage expenses: Wage growth has outpaced revenue growth and put downward pressure on profit. The industry requires highly skilled employees such as actuaries and claims investigators. In addition, wage expenses have outpaced revenue growth, leading to wage costs climbing as a share of revenue.

FAQs.question: How does your company go about managing various kinds of risk? How effective are these techniques?
FAQs.answer: To limit risk, diversification for insurers must be achieved across business lines, locations and reinsurance arrangements. Additionally, a diversified investment portfolio is essential to temper investment income volatility.

FAQs.question: What delivery system do you use? How do you ensure that it is cost-effective?
FAQs.answer: Insurers should have effective, low-cost product distribution channels. This typically involves the use of agents and brokers, banks, and a targeted retail presence.

FAQs.question: How do you ensure the accuracy of the information you provide? Have you ever had any issue with accuracy?
FAQs.answer: A large database of risk-related information enables insurers to price policies accurately and calculate requisite surplus levels. Lacking accurate information, models defining the price of risk become fundamentally flawed.

FAQs.question: How much of your revenue is generated by US residents on a trip? How have you mitigated the threat of fewer people travelling?
FAQs.answer: Consumers often take domestic flights to attend performances in other parts of the United States, therefore as domestic travel increases, so does demand for entertainment insurance.

FAQs.question: Have you experienced an increase in federal funding?
FAQs.answer: When theater performances and other artistic performances have high amounts of funding, they are less reliant on entertainment insurance.

FAQs.question: Do you track disposable income levels? Have you experienced an increased business due to rising disposable income?
FAQs.answer: As disposable income rises, people are better able to afford tickets for performances, increasing demand for entertainment insurance.
